title: Face of Medieval Scot 'with terrible teeth' is painstakingly recreated
text:
The face of a Medieval Scot with 'terrible teeth' has been painstakingly revealed from his 600-year-old skull using facial reconstruction technology.

The man's remains were found — along with almost 60 other full skeletons — as work began on the redevelopment of the Aberdeen Art Gallery in 2015.

Work was temporarily suspended to allow archaeologists to investigate — with the experts revealing insights into the health and lifestyle of those buried.

The facial reconstruction technology was used to produce an image of one man, whose remains are referred to as Skeleton (SK) 125.

Experts from the AOC Archaeology Group concluded he was over 46, between 5ft 2in and 5ft 5in and suffered from extensive dental issues.

These included lost teeth, gum disease, cavities and a chronic abscess.

The man's remains were found — along with almost 60 other full skeletons — as work began on the redevelopment of the Aberdeen Art Gallery in 2015

'SK 125 has provided us with a first fascinating glimpse of one of the people buried on the site of Aberdeen Art Gallery over 600 years ago,' said archaeologist Paula Milburn.

'The ongoing post-excavation work is examining the remains in detail.'

Such efforts, she added, 'will provide us with amazing information on the kind of people buried here, including their ages, gender, health and lifestyles.'

Evidence suggests the man was not local to Aberdeen but perhaps spent his childhood in an area such as the north-west Highlands or Outer Hebrides.

The art gallery was built in 1885 on the site of the former Blackfriars Dominican Friary, believed to have been founded between AD1222-1249.

The gallery on Schoolhill is due to reopen on Saturday.
